render.tex: \title{Integration by Parts:} Evaluating $\int f(x)\cdot g(x)\cdot dx$ ; Applying $ILATE$ to ease integration

reason.tex:
%text Given two functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ \[ \int f\cdot g\cdot dx = f\underbrace{\int g\cdot dx}_A - \underbrace{\int \left[f'\int g\cdot dx \right]\cdot dx}_{B}\] Note that there are \underline\text{2 separate integrals} to evaluate -- $A,$ and $B$ \textbf{ILATE} But what is $f(x)$ in, say, $\int x\cdot\sin x\cdot dx$? There are no right or wrong answers. Only better ones. In the table below, let \underline\text{$f(x)$} be the function that \underline\text{matches first } % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{ccMM}
\hline & \text{Meaning} & \text{Example} & \int x\sin x\cdot dx\\ \hline \text{I} & \text{Inverse Trig.} & \sin^{-1} x, \tan^{-1} x & \\ \hline \text{L} & \text{Logarithmic} & \log x & \\ \hline \text{A} & \text{Algebraic} & x^2, 4x^7 & f(x) =x \\ \hline \text{T} & \text{Trigonometric} & \sin x, \cos 3x & g(x) = \sin x \\ \hline \text{E} & \text{Exponential} & e^x, 7^x & \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text \textbf{An important result } Integration by parts also yields the following important result \[ \quad \int e^x\cdot \left[f(x) + f'(x) \right]\cdot dx = e^x\cdot f(x) + C \] %
